title: From TOWIE to Downton Abbey, the best of Britain's TV locations

Essex residents recently launched a bid to stop TOWIE tours in Brentwood over fears 'disruptive' hen dos could deter people from visiting.
But does being a location for a TV show always lead to an unhappy ending?
Here we tour the locations for Britain's top TV shows including Broadchurch, Downton Abbey and Game of Thrones and reveal how their fortunes have changed.
Locals fear Brentwood tours, based on reality TV show The Only Way Is Essex, are 'putting off a demographic' because they bring people from 'every corner of the UK' including lots of stag dos, hen dos and 'drunk people'
Hair we go: Amy Childs' Salon is a stopping point on the TOWIE tour in Brentwood, Essex
TOWIE - Essex
Locals fear Brentwood tours, based on reality TV show The Only Way Is Essex, are 'putting off a demographic' because they bring people from 'every corner of the UK' including lots of stag dos, hen dos and 'drunk people'.
Shoppers also claim they are put off visiting stores in the town, because they are intimidated by the large crowds drawn by the four-hour tours, which cost £26 for adults.

The shocking moment airline employee loses her cool during... Chris Hossack, a Tory councillor for Brentwood, said: 'We've got to give TOWIE credit where people who were starring in the early part of the show have been entrepreneurial and set themselves up delis and clothes shops and actually they're occupying retail units in Brentwood which might otherwise be empty.
'However, there's an opinion of quite a number of people in Brentwood that the tour side of things, this whole thing of people coming in from all four corners of the UK, hen nights, stag dos, walking around Brentwood with selfie sticks, it's just putting off a demographic of local people.'
Poldark - Cornwall
A survey showed that Scotland and Cornwall - where the BBC Poldark series was filmed - are the two top spots for tourists this year
Cornwall is set to cash in on the 'Poldark effect' with an upsurge of holiday bookings this summer
A map showing the filming locations for some of TV's most-loved shows
Picturesque scenes in Poldark spark Cornish property boom It seems BBC's steamy drama Poldark has left tourists eager to holiday in Cornwall, where the hit television show is set.
A shirtless Aidan Turner running through the fields in the south west county has won him, and the show, a legion of fans.
And now Cornwall itself is set to cash in on the 'Poldark effect' with an upsurge of holiday bookings this summer.
Nearly two in three of those polled said they intended taking a holiday in the UK this year, a survey by Post Office Travel Insurance found.
The survey showed that Scotland and Cornwall - where the BBC Poldark series was filmed - are the two top spots for tourists this year.
A Post Office Travel Insurance spokeswoman said: 'Cornwall tied top with Scotland as this year's most sought-after destination.
'But Cornwall's near neighbour and close competitor Devon was some way behind in fourth place, suggesting that the impact of the Poldark TV series has worked to Cornwall's advantage in the race to attract tourists.'
Downton Abbey
Downton Abbey has seen Highclere Castle in Hampshire becoming one of Britain's best-known stately homes, attracting as many as 1,200 visitors a day - all happily paying the £20 entry fee
Thanks to the success of the show, the stately home now gets thousands of visitors every day
Any fans of the period drama favourite Downton Abbey will instantly recognise the spectacular Highclere Castle in Hampshire as the home of Lord and Lady Grantham.
Prior to the show being shown on TV, the location needed £11.75million worth of repairs, including £1.8million of urgent work on the main house.
Thankfully the show has seen it become one of Britain's best-known stately homes, attracting as many as 1,200 visitors a day - all happily paying the £20 entry fee.
For the last series, it was rumoured the Carnarvons secured a £1 million filming fee.
The lavish location opens to visitors during spring and summer.
Game of Thrones - Northern Ireland
The HBO hit TV series has gripped viewers worldwide, many of whom are desperate to experience the incredible filming locations behind the show
The Wall could become a permanent feature in its County Antrim location in Northern Ireland, thanks to the keen interest of fans who wish to photograph it
The HBO hit TV series has gripped viewers worldwide, many of whom are desperate to experience the incredible filming locations behind the show.
From Doune Castle in Scotland to The Dark Hedges in Northern Ireland, many places have experienced a boost in interest.
Just last week local councillors near 'The Wall' set in County Antrim said they are petitioning to keep it a permanent fixture.
On the screen The Wall is a 300-mile barrier which separates the White Walkers, Wildlings and giants from the rest of the country.
In reality the spot is an old cement works, but due to the number of tourists who want to photograph it, the set could remain as a permanent Game of Thrones tribute.
East Antrim DUP MP Sammy Wilson said to PA: 'It is a magnificent site and it would be a massive tourist attraction. The number of buses and people who stop to try and get views of it.'
Broadchurch - West Bay, Dorset
In a poll commissioned by HBO Entertainment, West Bay in Dorset was the fifth most popular TV location to visit
One hotel booking website said interest in Broadchurch led to a 200 per cent increase in holiday searches for Dorset and Somerset
In a poll commissioned by HBO Entertainment, West Bay in Dorset, with its 80ft cliffs, was the fifth most desirable TV location to visit.
But there have been concerns over safety.
Many tourists risk a fatal fall from the crumbling edge of the cliffs or creating a landslip that could kill anyone passing below.
Ironically, the show's TV crew were themselves criticised for taking 'silly risks' as they set up their cameras just yards from a cliff edge while filming the current series.
One hotel booking website said interest in Broadchurch had already led to a 200 per cent increase in holiday searches for Dorset and Somerset, following the airing of the second season.
Meanwhile, the show is also having an effect on property prices.
The 100-year-old chalet in West Bay used in the series as the home of Detective Inspector Alec Hardy (Tennant) is for sale at £275,000.
The price is an example of what local estate agent Malcolm Gill calls the 'Broadchurch effect', which added up to £50,000 to its value.
Geordie Shore
The cast of Geordie Shore, who are known for their party-loving ways
The popular show, which has nearly a million viewers per episode, is filmed in Newcastle upon Tyne. Pictured is a view towards the city centre
Tourism bosses in the Lancashire area of Blackpool (pictured) revealed they refused permission for TV show Geordie Shore to shoot footage there, as it does not want to be cast in a 'detrimental light'
Despite wracking up nearly a million viewers per episode, it appears that not all UK destinations wish to be associated with the hit reality show from Newcastle.
Last year it was revealed that seaside town Blackpool banned MTV cameras from filming the cast enjoying wild nights out there because it does not want to be portrayed as Britain's answer to Magaluf.
The reality show had planned to film in pubs, clubs and strip bars before returning to more late-night drinking at their hotel.
Wolf Hall
The stunning filming locations of Wolf Hall have helped to ensure widespread acclaim for the big-budget period drama and there's been a surge in interest in them from tourists
Fans of Wolf Hall, which stars Damian Lewis as King Henry VIII, have been keen to see where the action was set
Take a look at the design of Tudor set for Wolf Hall It's not just the stellar cast that won over viewers of the BBC's blockbuster adaption of Wolf Hall.
The stunning scenery and filming locations have also helped to ensure widespread acclaim for the big-budget period drama. And tourists want to check them out.
During filming the cast and crew travelled up and down the country to some of its most popular visitor destinations, including Barrington Court in Somerset, Gloucester Cathedral and Lacock Abbey in Wiltshire.
National Trust predicted a 25 per cent increase in visitors throughout 2015.
Pride and Prejudice
The setting for the iconic wet suit scene from the TV adaptation of Pride and Prejudice was Lyme Park in Cheshire, and since the TV debut, visitor numbers almost tripled the following year
Many fans were keen to see where Pride and Prejudice, starring Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle, was filmed after its debut in 1995
Many fans were clearly enthralled by Mr Darcy emerging from the lake in the BBC TV adaptation of Pride and Prejudice in 1995.
The setting for the iconic moment was Lyme Park in Cheshire, and since the TV debut, visitor numbers almost tripled from 32,852 in 1994 to 91,437 in 1995.
John Woodward, chief executive of the UK Film Council, told the BBC : 'British films and television programmes play a powerful role in showcasing the UK to the rest of the world and boosting tourism.
'There are countless examples of visitors flocking to locations they've seen in films or on TV and the effect can last for years.'
